metadata.title: ADA/Accessibility Path-of-Travel Requirements
metadata.source: SF DBI DA-series Info Sheets + CBC Chapter 11B (2022) + DSA IR 11B-10

context: California accessibility requirements (CBC Chapter 11B) often EXCEED federal ADA requirements. SF enforces CBC Chapter 11B through DBI plan review. Both state and federal requirements must be met — the more restrictive applies.

valuation_threshold.source: DSA Access Compliance Reference Materials (updated annually based on ENR Construction Cost Index)
valuation_threshold.note: This threshold changes annually. Tools should check current value. The threshold determines whether full path-of-travel compliance is required or limited to 20% of construction cost.

core_logic.trigger: Any alteration, addition, or structural repair to an existing building or facility used as public building, public accommodation, commercial building, or public housing
core_logic.requirement: Provide accessible path of travel to the specific area of alteration or addition
path_of_travel_elements: 1. Primary entrance to the building (highest priority)
2. Toilet and bathing facilities serving the area
4. Public telephones serving the area (if any)
6. Route from entrance to altered area

below_threshold.rule: Path-of-travel compliance limited to 20% of adjusted construction cost
below_threshold.if_20pct_insufficient: Comply to greatest extent possible without exceeding 20%. Prioritize elements in order listed above.
below_threshold.documentation: DA-02 Checklist Form C — itemize accessibility upgrades. Total should be as close to 20% as possible.

above_threshold.rule: FULL path-of-travel compliance required to current CBC edition
above_threshold.exception: If enforcing agency determines full compliance creates unreasonable hardship, equivalent facilitation or compliance to greatest extent possible. But NEVER less than 20% of construction cost.
above_threshold.documentation: DA-02 Checklist with unreasonable hardship request if applicable

adjusted_construction_cost_includes: Utilities, contractor financing, overhead and profit
All altered elements including entrance, drinking fountains, signs if in area of alteration
adjusted_construction_cost_excludes: Utility connection or service district fees
Cost of path-of-travel upgrades themselves (don't count accessibility work toward the threshold)

buildings_without_elevators.rule: Previously approved buildings without elevators: areas above/below ground floor subject to 20% rule EVEN IF project exceeds valuation threshold
applies_to: Other buildings 3+ stories, 3000+ sqft/floor with public services on accessible level

change_of_use.rule: Change of use or occupancy triggers path-of-travel requirements for the new use area

seismic_mitigation.rule: Seismic retrofit projects (soft story, etc.) trigger path-of-travel obligations. Mixed-use buildings have specific requirements.
seismic_mitigation.common_scenario: Soft story retrofit in mixed-use building triggers accessibility upgrades for commercial ground floor

historic_buildings.rule: Alterations to qualified historic buildings shall comply with State Historical Building Code (Part 8, Title 24)
historic_buildings.note: More flexible requirements but still requires accessibility improvements

ev_charging.rule: EVCS installation at primary vehicle facilities: path-of-travel to max extent feasible without exceeding 20%. At non-primary vehicle facilities: no path-of-travel requirement.

common_corrections.description: No DA-02 checklist submitted with permit application
common_corrections.frequency: Very high — most common accessibility correction
common_corrections.fix: Submit DA-02 Disabled Access Upgrade Compliance Checklist Package with initial application for any commercial alteration.
Plans must show the accessible route from primary entrance to area of alteration, including all intermediate elements (doors, corridors, ramps, elevators).

common_corrections.description: Existing conditions not surveyed — plans say 'existing accessible' without verification
common_corrections.frequency: High — most common professional failing per DSA
common_corrections.fix: Design professionals must survey and document ACTUAL existing conditions, not assume compliance. Note specific dimensions of doors, clearances, slopes, restroom layouts.

common_corrections.description: Door widths, clearances, or hardware non-compliant
common_corrections.fix: Doors: 32-inch clear width minimum. Maneuvering clearance per CBC 11B-404.2.4. Hardware: operable with one hand, no tight grasping/twisting. Maximum 5 lbs opening force (interior).

common_corrections.description: Restroom non-compliant (turning radius, grab bars, fixture heights)
common_corrections.fix: 60-inch turning radius (or T-turn). Grab bars per CBC 11B-604. Toilet centerline 16-18 inches from side wall. Lavatory knee clearance.
Maximum ramp slope 1:12 (8.33%). Landings at top and bottom, and every 30 inches of rise. Handrails both sides.

common_corrections.description: Construction cost not properly calculated for threshold determination
common_corrections.fix: Adjusted construction cost must include ALL construction costs (labor, materials, equipment, profit) but exclude A&E fees, testing, utility fees, and the accessibility work itself.
Certified Access Specialist (CASp) inspection provides legal benefits and identifies issues early. SF offers reimbursement grants via Office of Small Business.

casp_information.what: Certified Access Specialist inspection — third-party accessibility audit
casp_information.benefit: Legal protection if accessibility claim arises. Early issue identification. May qualify for SF Accessible Barrier Removal Grant.
casp_information.find_inspector: CA Division of State Architect list: https://www.dgs.ca.gov/DSA/Resources
casp_information.sf_grants: Office of Small Business — Accessible Barrier Removal Grant can reimburse CASp inspection and improvements
